item.description:
7:00-7:30 pm - Socialize (please bring your own goodies if you want any!) ? I might bring a digital camera to post a photo of the meeting on our Meetup web site IF participants grant permission (please notify me of any privacy concerns).

7:30~9:00 pm - Decluttering Support: Round-table discussion
Sharing of decluttering successes and inspirations, group problem-solving, buddying up, + input to future Meetups: group SUCCESSION, future meeting topics and schedule, venue, speakers, organizers, activities, resources: how best to help YOU?

Parking available close by: On street parking is available on Homer Street, on the next block of Center Street just before Bow Street, and on Furber Lane behind the church.

Public transportation: Take the Riverside (Green) line to Newton Centre.

***

For inspiration:

* Lessons from a Goose: www.problogger.net/archives/2005/05/19/blogging-in-formation-lessons-from-a-goose

* Seabiscuit documentary about the beloved "little brown racehorse" who became proxy for this nation during the Great Depression: anatomically comical in respects (an "equine catastrophe!"), with an abysmal track record as a colt, Seabiscuit appeared best suited for hauling ice carts. But a wise trainer caught a certain look in his eye and took him on ? inspiring generations. Tears well in my eyes as I watch Seabiscuit's spirit spark and then focus, head to head against the magnificent, seemingly invincible War Admiral ? and race "to parts unknown!"

* Batteries ? plain commodities vital for many applications: music, work (even TASERS!). Each of us is like a battery: sometimes only one is needed for a job; usually more, to create synergy. Clutter MAY be a clue that more "batteries" are needed to complete a connection for the matter and energy stuck around us to flow again ? helping us do what we want MOST. How to better share the wealth we've collected and attract more batteries to "rock our world"? What's special about your stuff ? why keep it around? Might sharing about it help to release it?

* Saving Private Ryan movie opening scene: military risking their lives for our freedom to create value. (Also: clutter can't fight back!)

* Chocolate calcium "chews" vs. chalky tablets ? which do you suppose are used more often?

If you can't attend, let us know your wishes ? and ideas to make declutteringmore FUN, increasing our chances for success ? such as (friendly) competitions for:

- most $ earned by eBay/selling stuff
- most creative way to reward oneself
- the inspiration/strategy/technique/resource/organization/person most helpful for clearing clutter
- most progress made decluttering
- most value added to a space cleared of clutter
- best use/home found for stuff
- idea to make decluttering MOST FUN

?or find ways to best motivate YOU, to share at meetings or on our Message Board.

For those who requested suggestions to start NOW ? how about analyzing what's accumulating: most related to security (finances, job, work), sentiment (mementos), projects (reminders of to-do's)?? Often much of a problem can be attributed to relatively few causes ? e.g., 20% of organizations sending us junk mail may be responsible for 80% of our clutter! Determine the Worst Offenders and remove our names from the mailing lists to TURN OFF THE SPIGOT of junk into our lives.

Resources I've found helpful include:

* Mike Nelson, Stop Clutter from Stealing Your Life
* Stephanie Winston's & Julie Morgenstern's books
* David Allen, Getting Things Done
* Sallie Felton, www.salliefeltonlifecoach.com
* Disaster Masters, www.disposophobia.com online e-book, "101 Strategies to Master the Clutter"

Other resources (URLs, books, services) are on our Message Board. Thanks to Assistant Organizers Pamela, who set up our Board, and Marilyn, who has secured our venue!

IDEAS WELCOMED! You can often find me on Sunday late a.m.'s to brainstorm at: www.cambridgepres.com

The portal of our sorrow can become our Gateway to Joy. ? Elisabeth Elliot

Philippians 4:6-9 ? Thanks in All
